docs.snippet: A photo of Mr. Zuckerberg’s laptop camera covered in tape had curious observers wondering if it was paranoia or just good practice.

headline.main: Mark Zuckerberg Covers His Laptop Camera. You Should Consider It, Too.

docs.snippet: One test was canceled, and the Education Ministry, along with the police and military officers who guard the exams, faced a wave of criticism.

headline.print_headline: Criticism of Egypt’s Education System Intensifies After Leaks of Answers to National Exams
headline.main: Leaks of Answers Before Egypt’s National Exams Embarrass Government

docs.abstract: Egypt's Education Ministry faces public criticism after two annual high school exams called Thanaweya Amma, which determine entry to state-run universities and institutes, were leaked and posted on Facebook by person or group under moniker Chao Ming; high school student Mohanad Ahmed and 25 other people have been arrested in connection to leaked documents.

docs.snippet: Excise the idea of the extension of liberty from U.S. foreign policy and something very meager remains.
A professor writes, “These snippets may be live, but they conflate live information with news, and streaming as-it-happens video with truth.”
When the Anti-Defamation League hired Brittan Heller to work with tech companies against harassment, she was deluged with online attacks.

headline.main: What It’s Like to Fight Online Hate

docs.abstract: When the Anti-Defamation League hired Brittan Heller to work with tech companies against harassment, she was deluged with online attacks.

docs.snippet: Geofeedia, a company in Chicago, has used data from Facebook, Twitter and several other networks to aid law enforcement officials in monitoring protesters, the A.C.L.U. says.

headline.print_headline: Police Use Scanner of Social Networks to Monitor Protests
headline.main: Police Use Surveillance Tool to Scan Social Media, A.C.L.U. Says

docs.abstract: American Civil Liberties Union asserts Chicago firm Geofeedia is marketing a tool that uses text, photos and videos from major social media companies like Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to assist law enforcement surveillance of protesters.

docs.snippet: The Philando Castile shooting and its aftermath have catapulted services like Facebook Live and Periscope into the center of the news, challenging cable to adapt.

headline.print_headline: All the Power of Cable News in Your Palm
headline.main: Live Streaming Breaks Through, and Cable News Has Much to Fear

docs.snippet: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Richard Pérez-Peña, Sarah Lyall and others.
docs.abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Richard Pérez-Peña, Sarah Lyall and others.

docs.snippet: Nothing good. Experts suggested limiting your exposure to violent imagery and social media.

headline.main: What Is a Constant Cycle of Violent News Doing to Us?

docs.snippet: The rules will put new pressure on American tech companies, but European officials say they will unite the Continent’s various national economies.

headline.print_headline: Tech Firms See Protectionism in E.U. Plan to Unify Market
headline.main: E.U. Rules Look to Unify Digital Market, but U.S. Sees Protectionism
